articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: This article reports an unusually low number of comet discoveries for the year, with a historical analysis suggesting May's low discovery rate is due to ecliptic positioning favoring Northern Hemisphere observers. It highlights amateur comet hunter Don Machholz's upcoming appearances, including in People Magazine and a talk for the San Francisco Amateur Astronomers. Additionally, it provides an update on observing Jupiter's Great Red Spot, noting recent difficulties and its upcoming solar conjunction.

articles.title: New Addresses:
articles.summary: This document lists new contact addresses for Ron Cunha and Trudy E. Bell. Additionally, it includes several miscellaneous quotes from Patrick Moore, Denni, and Wolf Hanisch, covering topics like time travel and humorous observations.

articles.title: AVAILABLE PUBLICATIONS
articles.summary: The article lists various astronomical publications, including lunar quadrant maps, star atlases, and reference handbooks, available for purchase through a club at significant discounts (10%-45%) from Sky Publishing. Members can order these items, with prices ranging from $0.60 to $56.00, by contacting the club treasurer.

articles.title: ASTRONOMY DAYâ€”SJAA STYLE
articles.summary: Astronomy Day at the Rosicrucian Planetarium on April 7th successfully engaged about a hundred members of the public with numerous telescopes and activities. Attendees enjoyed viewing celestial objects like Jupiter, Saturn, the Moon, and M42 through 16 different instruments, often comparing views. The event also featured an outdoor slide show and a planetarium sky show, marking a well-received start to the star party season.

articles.title: SUCCESS!
articles.summary: The article recounts a group's challenging journey on February 26th to observe a total solar eclipse, starting with an early morning drive, navigational issues, and initial cloud cover. Despite these hurdles, they successfully found a viewing spot and witnessed the spectacular totality, capturing the event through astrophotography. The document also includes a brief news update on supernova discoveries in M100 and M101.

articles.title: SJAA Banquet
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is hosting its annual Banquet and officer installation as a picnic at Sanborn County Park on Sunday, July 15, starting at 3:00 PM. The event will feature a steak and 'Bender' beans dinner, horseshoe pits, and an informal star party at dusk, with attendees encouraged to bring potluck items and telescopes. Reservations for the event, priced at $4.00 for steak dinners, are due by June 22.

articles.title: How to Make Money and Become Famous at the Same Time
articles.summary: To address depleted club funds, a group of astronomers plans to sell astrophotography prints. Wolfgang Hanisch is organizing the effort, requesting black and white negatives from members to be enlarged, mounted, and sold for about $4.00 each. Each print will be signed by the photographer, include technical details, and bear the club's small logo, with all profits directed to the club's treasury.

articles.title: The Messier Marathon - a First Report
articles.summary: This report details a multi-night Messier Marathon event, where participants attempted to observe as many Messier objects as possible. Observers achieved high counts, with some completing the entire Messier Catalogue for awards, while also witnessing unique celestial phenomena like a rocket launch barium dump, a large fireball meteor, and a re-entering Russian satellite. The event was deemed successful, and the Loma Prieta Site proved suitable for future use.

articles.title: Finest Skalnate Pleso Objects - Chart II, conclusion
articles.summary: This article, titled "Finest Skalnate Pleso Objects - Chart II, conclusion," provides detailed observational guides for numerous deep-sky objects from the Skalnate Pleso Catalogue, including various NGC and Messier objects. It offers specific advice for amateur astronomers on viewing planetary nebulae, open clusters, and gaseous nebulae, detailing optimal magnification, visibility challenges, and distinctive features to look for. The guide emphasizes techniques like averted vision and proper power settings to enhance the viewing experience of these celestial targets.
